pullRequest.body:
Add definition Lindelöf set, Lindelöf space, non-Lindelöf space. 
Add copyright header

nodes.body:
@grunweg Thank you for your kind words! I thought I'd keep the PR as small as possible to ensure that the definition is accepted before I'd sink a lot of work in working out the basic API. I looked at the API for Compact, and at first sight, the first few results seem to have clear analogues for Lindelöf, so I'm planning to get some work in on these during my daily commute. I'm not sure how quick this will go, the first two theorems took me relatively little time yesterday, but I'm still getting the hang of Lean (I worked through MIL), so I'll most probably hit some steep learning curves at some parts. 

I don't intend to work on adding examples (at this point), but I'll try to add (some of) the obvious implications (compact => Lindelöf etc.) at some point.

@grunweg I just updated the PR, it now includes some results that pave the way towards "X is Lindelöf iff every cover has a countable subcover". The current PR is 150 lines, I guess that is a good size to make the reviewing manageable? 

I will keep deriving the rest of the needed results as the week progresses, but perhaps it is better to put these in a new PR to keep the chunks a bit smaller?

About 2 years ago, I made a similar PR to Mathlib 3 but failed to get it merged before it rot. You may want to look at it for the list of useful results: https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib/pull/11716
I'm going to review your PR tomorrow. Thanks a lot for working on this!

@grunweg thank you for your remarks, I will incorporate them and make an updated PR soon, hopefully today. I'll probably halt adding new results and features until the current items are added to mathlib. 

@urkud thank you, I'll definitely look there for inspiration if I'm adding new components. Did you consider an equivalent definition of Lindelöf spaces in terms of ultrafilters? I could not find anything on this online, I tried eyeballing a definition (just add [CountableInterFilter] to the ultrafilter definition of IsCompact) but found that it would need some refinements of existing ultrafilter results, e.g. this one https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/217875-Is-there-code-for-X.3F/topic/Specialising.20forall_neBot_le_iff.20to.20countable.20intersection/near/409457323. I'll try to incorporate the review by grunweg today and make a new PR!

@urkud, I've incorporated all of the feedback by @grunweg in the most recent PR. I'm not certain if it is better to use Lindelöf or Lindelof in the actual object names, I feel that accents may become a bit unwieldy, but I'm happy to change that if you prefer!

@grunweg, what do you mean with this request exactly? LindelofSpace is more towards the bottom of the file now, in line with the placement of CompactSpace in Compact.lean. 
https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/9107#discussion_r1434552681

Oh my, it seems Github is unhelpful here. I referred to my previous comment; now I see they're shown separately.

@JADekker What I meant is: Can you change the docstring of LindelofSpace` to something more descriptive, such as "X is Lindelöf space iff every open cover has a countable subcover"?
Thank you for clarifying, I made a commit.
Please ensure that every instance that applies to all spaces (e.g., "every second-countable topology is Lindelof") has low priority. We want Lean to try type-specific instances first.

> Please ensure that every instance that applies to all spaces (e.g., "every second-countable topology is Lindelof") has low priority. We want Lean to try type-specific instances first.

Done, I hope! Please do let me know if I misinterpreted this!

After these few changes, please merge `master`, make sure that CI is happy and merge. Thanks!

bors d+

P.S.: After it lands, I'm going to split this file into smaller pieces but let's already merge it without waiting for this.

:v: JADekker can now approve this pull request. To approve and merge a pull request, simply reply with `bors r+`. More detailed instructions are available [here](https://bors.tech/documentation/getting-started/#reviewing-pull-requests).
@urkud thanks,I’ll merge master and the changes when I get in the office today!
bors r+

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/7582731329/job/20652888931)
  * [Check all files imported](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/7582731329/job/20652888443)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/7582731329/job/20652888733)

Just four more comments/bits of advice about style.
Since @urkud will take a look, I'll defer the higher-level pieces to them.

Welcome to mathlib and thanks for contributing! A few months back, I realised mathlib didn't have this concept, made a mental note to return to this and moved on to other things. I'm happy to see that you're adding this definition now. Thank you for doing this!

It looks like you already did all the general style things right. I only have three very minor comments. Mostly, I have suggestions what what you could do next :-) --- perhaps you know this already!

You have added some definitions; the next step is adding some "API" (basic lemmas you'd need to work with this definition). You basically already have
- `X` is a Lindelöf space iff `univ` is Lindelöf; if `X` is Lindelöf, `univ` is ([similar](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Topology/Compactness/Compact.html#isCompact_univ_iff) to compact sets)

I would be nice to also prove (but I don't know much work this is):
- `X` is Lindelöf iff every open cover has a countable subcover

Other useful lemmas I can think of, off the top of my head --- I think this PR has enough space for some of them; these can also be follow-up PRs:
- the empty set is Lindelöf
- countable unions of Lindelöf spaces are Lindelöf
- images of Lindelöf spaces are Lindelöf
- a closed subspace of a Lindelöf space is Lindelöf
- are there useful results about intersections?

If you're feeling ambitious, issue #7178 has some ideas for future PRs. (One more idea: can you give examples of Lindelöf or non-examples? (Does mathlib have e.g. the long line already? It might not.)) I'm just mentioning these to show the range of possibilities; you absolutely don't have to do these yourself!

Overall: you added quite a lot of material; that's really nice to see!

I haven't digested all the maths proofs; I left a number of comments on documentation, about mathlib's preferred coding style and opportunities to ["golf"](https://leanprover-community.github.io/glossary.html#golfing) your code (the glossary is written for Lean 3, but this item applies well).
These are a lot of comments - I decided to tell you a lot of small tricks at once. Getting so many comments initially is completely normal.

Just FYI; I'll be on holiday until January 5th and not looking at mathlib.

Just four more comments/bits of advice about style.
Since @urkud will take a look, I'll defer the higher-level pieces to them.

Do you really need to open `Classical`?
```suggestion

open Set Filter Topology TopologicalSpace

Not yet, but I've skimmed through the first dozen theorems in Compact, and they seem to carry over relatively easily to Lindelöf, so I thought I'd just leave Classical in there already; but you're right, it is not necessary as is.
```suggestion
I'd rather have this docstring say what a Lindelöf space is. For instance: "`X` is Lindelöf space iff every open cover has a countable subcover".
That is a good point, I'll add that definition, hopefully tomorrow. I didn't mention it yet, as I hadn't officially established that yet
Now that you have added it, can you add this?

I wonder whether mathlib prefers "Nonlindelöf" or "NonLindelöf". (My gut feeling says the latter; "noncompact" is American English, whereas "Lindelöf" is a proper name and not an adjective.) In any case, I'll defer to a more experienced reviewer.

**[lint-style]** reported by [reviewdog](https://github.com/reviewdog/reviewdog) :dog:
```suggestion (hf : ∀ x ∈ s, sᶜ ∈ 𝓝 x ⊓ f) : sᶜ ∈ f := by ```

**[lint-style]** reported by [reviewdog](https://github.com/reviewdog/reviewdog) :dog:
```suggestion [CountableInterFilter f] (hf : ∀ x ∈ s, ∃ t ∈ 𝓝[s] x, tᶜ ∈ f) : sᶜ ∈ f := by ```

**[lint-style]** reported by [reviewdog](https://github.com/reviewdog/reviewdog) :dog:
```suggestion : IsLindelof (f '' s) := hs.image_of_continuousOn hf.continuousOn ```

**[lint-style]** reported by [reviewdog](https://github.com/reviewdog/reviewdog) :dog:
```suggestion (hmono : ∀ ⦃s t⦄, s ⊆ t → p t → p s) ```

**[lint-style]** reported by [reviewdog](https://github.com/reviewdog/reviewdog) :dog:
```suggestion IsLindelof (f '' s) := by ```

**[lint-style]** reported by [reviewdog](https://github.com/reviewdog/reviewdog) :dog:
```suggestion IsLindelof (f '' s) := hs.image_of_continuousOn hf.continuousOn ```

**[lint-style]** reported by [reviewdog](https://github.com/reviewdog/reviewdog) :dog:
```suggestion have he : ∃ r : Set ι, r.Countable ∧ ∅ ⊆ ⋃ i ∈ r, U i := by use ∅; simp ```
Can you fill in this section, please?
Will do, I'd say that there is no 'main result' yet, but I could write the filter def <-> countable subcover def here.

You can be more precise if you name your set, such as the following. (As a bonus, this shows all the required arguments for the lemma, giving the user a feeling how to use this.)
Personally, I would delete the second sentence (or move this to a section "implementation notes". As a user, I shouldn't really need to care *how* this is implemented.

```suggestion
* `IsLindelöf s`: every open cover of `s` has a countable subcover

What do you think about this? (Before coming to mathlib, I'd seen Lindelöf spaces, but not Lindelöf sets. In any case, you have a lemma below showing this equivalence.)

* `LindelofSpace`: `X` is Lindelöf iff every open cover has a countable subcover
This docstring is outdated now

Two suggestions:
- In new code, `refine` is preferred over `refine'`. (There was a zulip thread about this recently; my understanding is that existing calls will be migrated automatically at some point.) In most cases, you just need to replace `_` by `?_`.
- $\mapsto$ is slightly preferred over "=>". You can type the former as \map or \mapsto in VS Code.
Thanks, replaced!
You can golf the last two lines to `exact fun x ⟨h₁, h₂⟩ hs \mapsto h₂ (h₁ hs)` (I think; untested).

Does it make sense to extract this filter into its own definition?
(My intuition is wondering if we have this in mathlib already. It might make sense to ask on zulip. If not, this could be a useful definition in its own right.)
I'll ask, I'll leave it in for now and refactor at a later stage if we decide on extracting the definition.
You may want to use `Filter.ofCountableInter` here or add `Filter.complOfCountableUnion` and use it. This way you get `CountableInterFilter` for free.
Thank you, I was planning to do that indeed, I was planning to add Filter.complOfCountableUnion as a follow-up for #9200 and then make a PR to update Lindelöf.lean accordingly
Did you know that you can combine intros and rcases into `rintro`?
Oops, forgot about that! Thanks!
Wait, isn't "within its image" wrong --- `f '' S` is Lindelöf in `Y`, right? I would just delete that clause.
Yes!

Per the [style guide](https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/style.html),
I'd rather spell this as differently: right now, you can't use dot notation on this theorem, for instance.
`theorem IsCompact.isLindelof (hs : IsCompact s) : isLindelof s := sorry`

Often, you can combine two subsequent lines of apply into one.
(Whether this is better depends on the proof.)In this case, I think it is - you could golf this e.g. to
`exact (countable_bInter_mem htc).mpr (fun i hi ↦ hUl _ (hts _ hi))`.

This also applies to a number of other places, above and below this one.

In mathlib, we'd like to avoid a bare `simp` call in the middle of a proof. `simp only` is fine (you can use `simp?` to find such an invocation), as is using `simp` when it closes a goal.

In mathlib jargon, these are called "non-terminal simps". They are harder to maintain over time (and using `simp only` can be slightly faster). The [glossary](https://leanprover-community.github.io/glossary.html#non-terminal-simp) (beware, written for Lean 3!) explains a bit more why they're avoided.

You have these in a number of other places.
Thanks, I've cleaned these up!

I would inline this `have` at its only usage site.
You can also combine subsequent `intro`s; then the last three lines could look like `exact fun is x hx ↦ mem_biUnion is ((hr i is).2 hx)`.

You could golf this into one line: `exact hS.biUnion_iff.mpr (fun s hs ↦ (hr s hs).1)`.

(In general, it's a matter of style and taste how far to golf code. The general rule is to stop when it makes code unreadable; "if nothing really happens", golfing down to one line is fine. In this case, this subgoal has almost no math content, so I think golfing this is good.)

You can also use refine here, as in `refine ⟨⋃ s ∈ S, r s, ?_, ?_⟩`.
Then you can even inline the proof of the first subgoal.

You can use dot notation here, as in
```suggestion
  have : tᶜ ∩ t ∈ 𝓝[tᶜ] x := inter_mem_nhdsWithin _ (ht₁.mem_nhds this)
```
 
Likewise in a few other places.
Combining the `apply`'s and inlining them, you can golf this to `exact { isLindelof_univ := isCompact_univ.isLindelof }`. (And then, `by` followed by `exact` can be replaced by just that proof term.
Why not use `where` notation here?

I'm not sure if making this an `instance` (as opposed to a theorem) is wise. (I don't have good intuition for this yet.)
An experienced reviewer should comment on this.

This would be a good place to put two lemmas
- "X is a Lindelöf space iff univ is Lindelöf
- -if X is Lindelöf, univ is

These are mathematically obvious from your definition; such lemmas will be useful for working with Lindelöf spaces in mathlib.
Added!
Another trick: you can inline the first subgoal via `by simp`. (Also, you can remove the commented code.)

As a closing tactic, `exact` is preferred over `refine` or `apply`. (In this case, you can just remove the `by refine`, just giving a proof term.)
You have at least one other such place.
You can probably also condense the subsequent lines a bit.

Some more general advice on mathlib style: if you just have two subgoals, I think "constructor" might be more readable. In this case, you can combine these into one line.
`refine ⟨U i, mem_nhdsWithin_of_mem_nhds ((hUo i).mem_nhds hi), {i}, by simp, ?_⟩`

While lots of API about compact sets is written with `f ≤ 𝓟 s` assumptions here and there, I think that having assumptions in non-simp form is not a good design decision. I would assume `s ∈ f` instead. But AFAIK we don't have coding style guidelines for this.

I agree that 's in f' may be more elegant, I just tried to keep as close to Compact as possible. Would you like me to change these? I'll make a PR with the other changes in the meanwhile, I'm happy to make a new one with this specific change!
Do you plan to add any instances of this typeclass? Any theorems about it?
Yes, but I wanted to keep the PR small! I have about twice as much code about Lindelöf spaces lying arounds, including some basic results about it. Do you want me to add them to this PR already?
This lemma (and the previous one) follow from `Set.Countable.isLindelof` (not yet in the PR).
Set.Countable.isLindelof requires some other dependencies, like Set.Countable.isLindelof_biUnion, which I have all finished but omitted from the PR to keep it small. Would you like me to add them?
One more typeclass I added in my PR is `StronglyLindelofSpace` assuming that every open set is Lindelof and implying that every set is Lindelof.
Yes, I saw that one, thought it'd be a good follow up PR to add the API for Strongly/Hereditarily Lindelöf spaces! Would you like them in this PR already?

The module docstring is a good place to discuss equivalent definitions of the notions defined in this file, explain why these notions are useful etc. In this case, you should

- Say that Lindelöf sets/spaces can be defined via filters or via open subcovers. Currently, it looks like you're using 2 different definitions for `IsLindelof` and `LindelofSpace`.
- The API is based on the API of `IsCompact` (e.g., in the "Implementation Notes" section).
- A second-countable topological space is strongly Lindelöf.
- A countable set is Lindelöf; more generally, a countable union of Lindelöf sets is Lindelöf.
- A σ-compact space is Lindelöf and a locally compact Lindelöf space is σ-compact.
- Give or reference an example of a non-Lindelöf set.

I know that many existing module level docstrings are very short but we're trying to improve the documentation, starting with new files. The goal is to make the module docstrings readable for mathematicians who never saw the concepts discussed in the file before.
Thanks, I was not aware of that indeed. Most of these results are not yet in the PR, so I'll write in the module docstring what I have.
IMHO, "has a cluster point in `s`" is good enough. Also, please reference the filter-free definition `isLindelof_iff_countable_subcover` here.

I think that this definition doesn't work for any set `s`. E.g., if `s` has no interior points, then it is hereditarily Lindelöf in the sense of this definition. Should it be something like this?
```
∀ t, IsOpen t → IsLindelof (t ∩ s)
```
Please verify that your definition is correct by proving
```
lemma IsHereditarilyLindelof.isLindelof_subset (hs : IsHereditarilyLindelof s) (ht : t ⊆ s) :
    IsLindelof s := _
```
Please add `LindelofSpace.of_continuous_surjective` constructor.
Done!
Instances like this one should have lower priority.

I think that this definition doesn't work for any set `s`. E.g., if `s` has no interior points, then it is hereditarily Lindelöf in the sense of this definition. Should it be something like this?
```lean
∀ t, IsOpen t → IsLindelof (t ∩ s)
```
Please verify that your definition is correct by proving
```lean
lemma IsHereditarilyLindelof.isLindelof_subset (hs : IsHereditarilyLindelof s) (ht : t ⊆ s) :
    IsLindelof t := _

lemma IsHereditarilyLindelof.isLindelof (hs : IsHereditarilyLindelof s) :
    IsLindelof s := hs.isLindelof_subset Subset.rfl
```
Perhaps requiring `IsOpen` is a bit clumsy, I'll just get rid of it here (as the official definition doesn't require it either!) and remove the lemma that concluded the more general case!

I think that we should have an instance
```lean
instance HereditarilyLindelof.lindelofSpace_subtype [HereditarilyLindelofSpace X] (p : X → Prop) :
    LindelofSpace s := _
```

and

```lean
lemma IsLindelof.of_coe [LindelofSpace s] : IsLindelof s := _
```

I've added my interpretation of `instance HereditarilyLindelof.lindelofSpace_subtype` and the lemma (first is near the end of the file, other one is a bit further up. After I make the commit, please let me know what you think, or if I used the wrong interpretation!

```suggestion
    (hcountable_union : ∀ (S : Set (Set X)), S.Countable → (∀ s ∈ S, p s) → p (⋃₀ S))
```

With the previous suggestion:
```suggestion
  let f : Filter X := ofCountableUnion p hcountable_union (fun t ht _ hsub ↦ hmono hsub ht)
```

```suggestion
  exact hs inf_le_right
```

```suggestion
    [SecondCountableTopology X] : HereditarilyLindelofSpace X where
  isHereditarilyLindelof_univ := fun t _ _ ↦ by
```

```suggestion
instance (priority := 100) SecondCountableTopology.toHereditarilyLindelof
```

```suggestion
    LindelofSpace X where
  isLindelof_univ := HereditarilyLindelofSpace.isHereditarilyLindelof_univ.isLindelof
```

You shouldn't need this instance.

```suggestion
```

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat: add Lindelöf spaces and sets

nodes.body:
Welcome to mathlib and thanks for contributing! A few months back, I realised mathlib didn't have this concept, made a mental note to return to this and moved on to other things. I'm happy to see that you're adding this definition now. Thank you for doing this!

It looks like you already did all the general style things right. I only have three very minor comments. Mostly, I have suggestions what what you could do next :-) --- perhaps you know this already!

You have added some definitions; the next step is adding some "API" (basic lemmas you'd need to work with this definition). You basically already have
- `X` is a Lindelöf space iff `univ` is Lindelöf; if `X` is Lindelöf, `univ` is ([similar](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Topology/Compactness/Compact.html#isCompact_univ_iff) to compact sets)

I would be nice to also prove (but I don't know much work this is):
- `X` is Lindelöf iff every open cover has a countable subcover

Other useful lemmas I can think of, off the top of my head --- I think this PR has enough space for some of them; these can also be follow-up PRs:
- the empty set is Lindelöf
- countable unions of Lindelöf spaces are Lindelöf
- images of Lindelöf spaces are Lindelöf
- a closed subspace of a Lindelöf space is Lindelöf
- are there useful results about intersections?

If you're feeling ambitious, issue #7178 has some ideas for future PRs. (One more idea: can you give examples of Lindelöf or non-examples? (Does mathlib have e.g. the long line already? It might not.)) I'm just mentioning these to show the range of possibilities; you absolutely don't have to do these yourself!

@grunweg Thank you for your kind words! I thought I'd keep the PR as small as possible to ensure that the definition is accepted before I'd sink a lot of work in working out the basic API. I looked at the API for Compact, and at first sight, the first few results seem to have clear analogues for Lindelöf, so I'm planning to get some work in on these during my daily commute. I'm not sure how quick this will go, the first two theorems took me relatively little time yesterday, but I'm still getting the hang of Lean (I worked through MIL), so I'll most probably hit some steep learning curves at some parts. 

I don't intend to work on adding examples (at this point), but I'll try to add (some of) the obvious implications (compact => Lindelöf etc.) at some point.

@grunweg I just updated the PR, it now includes some results that pave the way towards "X is Lindelöf iff every cover has a countable subcover". The current PR is 150 lines, I guess that is a good size to make the reviewing manageable? 

I will keep deriving the rest of the needed results as the week progresses, but perhaps it is better to put these in a new PR to keep the chunks a bit smaller?

Overall: you added quite a lot of material; that's really nice to see!

I haven't digested all the maths proofs; I left a number of comments on documentation, about mathlib's preferred coding style and opportunities to ["golf"](https://leanprover-community.github.io/glossary.html#golfing) your code (the glossary is written for Lean 3, but this item applies well).
These are a lot of comments - I decided to tell you a lot of small tricks at once. Getting so many comments initially is completely normal.

Just FYI; I'll be on holiday until January 5th and not looking at mathlib.

About 2 years ago, I made a similar PR to Mathlib 3 but failed to get it merged before it rot. You may want to look at it for the list of useful results: https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib/pull/11716
I'm going to review your PR tomorrow. Thanks a lot for working on this!

@grunweg thank you for your remarks, I will incorporate them and make an updated PR soon, hopefully today. I'll probably halt adding new results and features until the current items are added to mathlib. 

@urkud thank you, I'll definitely look there for inspiration if I'm adding new components. Did you consider an equivalent definition of Lindelöf spaces in terms of ultrafilters? I could not find anything on this online, I tried eyeballing a definition (just add [CountableInterFilter] to the ultrafilter definition of IsCompact) but found that it would need some refinements of existing ultrafilter results, e.g. this one https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/217875-Is-there-code-for-X.3F/topic/Specialising.20forall_neBot_le_iff.20to.20countable.20intersection/near/409457323. I'll try to incorporate the review by grunweg today and make a new PR!

@urkud, I've incorporated all of the feedback by @grunweg in the most recent PR. I'm not certain if it is better to use Lindelöf or Lindelof in the actual object names, I feel that accents may become a bit unwieldy, but I'm happy to change that if you prefer!

@grunweg, what do you mean with this request exactly? LindelofSpace is more towards the bottom of the file now, in line with the placement of CompactSpace in Compact.lean. 
https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/9107#discussion_r1434552681

Oh my, it seems Github is unhelpful here. I referred to my previous comment; now I see they're shown separately.

@JADekker What I meant is: Can you change the docstring of LindelofSpace` to something more descriptive, such as "X is Lindelöf space iff every open cover has a countable subcover"?
Thank you for clarifying, I made a commit.

Just four more comments/bits of advice about style.
Since @urkud will take a look, I'll defer the higher-level pieces to them.
Please ensure that every instance that applies to all spaces (e.g., "every second-countable topology is Lindelof") has low priority. We want Lean to try type-specific instances first.

> Please ensure that every instance that applies to all spaces (e.g., "every second-countable topology is Lindelof") has low priority. We want Lean to try type-specific instances first.

Done, I hope! Please do let me know if I misinterpreted this!

After these few changes, please merge `master`, make sure that CI is happy and merge. Thanks!

bors d+

P.S.: After it lands, I'm going to split this file into smaller pieces but let's already merge it without waiting for this.

:v: JADekker can now approve this pull request. To approve and merge a pull request, simply reply with `bors r+`. More detailed instructions are available [here](https://bors.tech/documentation/getting-started/#reviewing-pull-requests).
@urkud thanks,I’ll merge master and the changes when I get in the office today!
bors r+

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:

source.title: second countable spaces are Lindelöf (this is mostly already done here)
